article_title: Recent deluge illustrates widespread risk of flooding across the Charleston area
article_text:
The past week’s deluge across the Greater Charleston area brought tales of hours-long commutes, people being rescued from water-logged neighborhoods by boat, and the now-routine photos of cars stuck on flooded streets and people kayaking in unusual places.

The combination of unusually high “king” tides and rainfall that exceeded 6 inches in some areas Aug. 31 — not to mention the recent 10-year anniversary of Hurricane Katrina — also caused some people to learn, the hard way, that their home or business faces a greater flood risk than they thought.

Flood-related risks have been rising in the Lowcountry — along with sea levels, the amount of land covered by pavement or buildings, and incidences of extreme weather. Flood insurance premiums have been rising, too, as the National Flood Insurance Program deals with a massive deficit of about $24 billion and raises rates to better reflect the risks.

For anyone who owns a home or business, or is thinking about buying one, this is becoming an increasingly important financial issue. As flood insurance costs rise, so does the expense of owning property that’s in a flood zone. And as the cost of ownership rises, the value of some properties could be hurt.

This isn’t just about waterfront property. Consider that 60 percent of the homes built in Charleston County in the years just before the recession were built in the flood plain. There’s not a great deal of high ground in the Lowcountry.

There are plenty of Charleston area neighborhoods and subdivisions where some homes are in a flood zone and others are not. Outside a flood zone, flood insurance is optional and far less expensive. Within a flood zone, insurance would be required for owners with a mortage, and that could add hundreds of dollars, or even more, to the monthly cost of ownership.

For those who aren’t in a flood zone, or don’t have a mortgage, flood insurance becomes a question of weighing risks and costs — the bottom line with any insurance decision. In a state where 24-hour rainfall records have exceeded a foot of water in some counties, in a coastal area where the storm surge from a Hugo-sized hurricane could exceed 20 feet, there’s a lot of risk to consider.

One important financial factor to remember is South Carolina’s income tax credit for homeowners with excessive insurance costs. It’s not complicated and can ease the financial pain of high home insurance costs, but it’s clear from the number of people who have claimed the tax credit that it’s not well-known.

Here’s how the state’s Excess Insurance Premium Tax Credit works: If the cost of insuring your primary residence exceeds 5 percent of your federal adjusted gross income, the state will cover the difference, up to $1,250 yearly, as a credit on your state income tax return. The tax credit reduces the income tax you owe the state, dollar for dollar.

So once the cost of insuring your home hits 5 percent of your income, the state will essentially pay the next $1,250 in premiums. However, if you don’t owe income tax to the state — as is the case for many retired people — then you can’t take advantage of the tax credit.

Flooding is a risk for renters, too, and it’s important to remember that renters insurance typically does not cover damage from flooding (other than flooding caused by a pipe bursting in the rented structure). Renters, like owners, can get flood insurance through the National Flood Insurance Program.

Renters should not rely on a landlord’s assurance that a property doesn’t flood, or hasn’t flooded in the past, but should check a property’s flood map rating. Any property can escape flooding for years, yet still face a relatively high risk.

For example, a 1 percent annual chance of flooding doesn’t sound like much chance at all, but that’s the definition of a 100-year flood risk, and defines the federal high-risk “AE” flood zone. The Charlestowne Village Mobile Home Park off Dorchester Road, where flooding caused extensive damage, is in such a zone according to Federal Emergency Management Agency maps.

Want to get some idea of your risk? You can visit floodsmart.gov and type in your address to check. It’s the official website of the National Flood Insurance Program.

Want more details? Visit FEMA’s Flood Map Service Center online at msc.fema.gov and see the flood plain maps. The maps can be tricky to navigate online, but instead of just getting a general idea of your property’s flood risk, you can see the boundaries of different flood zones and get a better idea of where you stand.

Note that federal flood maps are being updated, so the high-risk flood areas could change. To see when the flood map for your community will be updated, click the “new flood maps” option on the floodsmart.gov website. Many of those new maps are scheduled to take effect, for flood insurance rates, late next year.
